Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Assessment of Cascading Failures and Collective Recovery of Interdependent Critical Infrastructure in Catastrophic Disasters: A Study of 2015 Earthquake in Nepal

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this Rapid Response Research (RAPID) project is to collect time-bound data on the nature, impacts, and recovery process related to cascading infrastructure failures from the 2015 Earthquake in Nepal. Due to the growing frequency and magnitude of natural disasters, understanding of the relationship between interdependencies and cascading failures in infrastructure systems is critical for strategic investments to enhance community resilience. The outcomes of this research will include a database of cascading failures and associated attributes and variables in interdependent infrastructure systems, which can be utilized to inform planning and decision making processes. By studying the pre-disaster infrastructure interdependencies, post-disaster cascading failures, and restoration interdependencies, this study will help policymakers in the United States, Nepal, and other countries prone to disasters to establish methods and processes to integrate resilience into their infrastructure planning and strategic investment efforts.

Despite emerging knowledge on resilient infrastructure systems, the number of empirical studies related to cascading failures and collective recovery of interdependent infrastructure is rather limited. This RAPID project addresses this gap in knowledge by collecting and analyzing data related to the power grid, transportation, water, sewage, and communication networks from the 2015 Earthquake in Nepal. The data to be collected will include primary and secondary infrastructure failures, failure modes, duration of service disruption, pre- and post-disaster conditions and performance, and post-disaster infrastructure restoration. These data will be collected through local infrastructure agencies and direct field observations. Geo-tagged photos and videos of infrastructure failures and damages will be used along with GIS information to capture and document the nature and the extent of cascading infrastructure failures across space and time. The other group of data to be collected is related to the decision making processes of infrastructure agencies for restoration and recovery of infrastructure systems. The primary method for collecting these data will include in-depth interviews with elected and appointed public officials at local and national levels involved in restoration and recovery efforts. Finally, a public survey will be conducted to collect data related to extent and duration of disruptions in infrastructure services in Kathmandu, Nepal. The collected data will be analyzed through the use of statistical and network analysis methods. In addition, a meta-network analysis will be conducted to answer the questions of who, what, why, how, and when to better understand restoration interdependency in infrastructure systems. The collected empirical data could be used as a foundation for verification and validation of the existing analytical models related to cascading infrastructure failures. Hence, the results will enable better understanding of the nature and impacts of cascading failures in interdependent infrastructure systems. In addition, this research will advance the understanding of the dynamics of restoration interdependency and provide insight into ways to influence the collective recovery of infrastructure systems in the aftermath of a catastrophic disaster.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Infrastructure systems play a critical role in the resilience of communities in natural disasters. This study aimed to address an important knowledge gap related to examining resilience in intermittent infrastructure of communities in developing countries. To this end, this rapid response study collected time-bound data related to infrastructure systems (e.g., water, electricity, and roadways) in Kathmandu Valley in the aftermath of the 2015 Nepal Earthquake.

This project is significant for several reasons. First, infrastructure resilience in developing countries is an understudied area of research. This study was among very few studies to evaluate the resilience of infrastructure systems in Nepal. Second, this study collected empirical information on the vulnerabilities of infrastructure systems in Nepal in order to build infrastructure back better. The existing capacity of governmental infrastructure agencies in Nepal did not enable them to consider resilience performance while planning for recovery. Hence, the information collected in this study provides valuable input to these agencies to enhance their recovery planning. Third, this study examined the interrelationship between infrastructure systems’ service disruption and the efficiency of humanitarian aid response processes. While the existing literature highlights the significance of infrastructure services in disaster response, the extent of this dependency was not quantified before. The information and methods used in this study quantitatively highlighted the extent to which disaster aid response processes depend upon infrastructure services. This information further emphasizes the need for improving infrastructure resilience in communities. Fourth, this study provided empirical evidence regarding the type of infrastructure damages and service disruptions and the extent to which these damages affect communities. This empirical information complements the analytical models in the literature for a better understanding of the impacts of natural disasters on infrastructure and communities. 

Summary of Findings

The research team conducted three visits to Nepal between September 2015 and May 2016. In each visit, two research team members travelled to Nepal. During these visits, the research team collected data through reconnaissance field trips, agency interviews, a community focus group, and a household survey. The results of these activities led to 355 geo-tagged photos of infrastructure damages, 47 in-depth interviews with 52 individuals in national and international infrastructure and aid agencies, and 224 household surveys. Based on these research activities, the following findings were obtained:

  1. This study highlighted the important role society’s adaptive capacity plays in coping with disaster impacts. Despite the fragile infrastructure, Nepalese communities were resilient in that they used substitutes to address their needs for water and electricity while infrastructure services were disrupted.
  2. The infrastructure systems in Nepal provide intermittent service. While the intermittent nature of infrastructure services reduced the interdependencies between the systems; it created new types of dependencies. For example, the supply of water using trucks created a dependency between water supply services and road infrastructure.
  3. Infrastructure disruptions significantly affected the response processes of domestic and international aid agencies. In Nepal, the delays in restoration of infrastructure services (e.g., road repairs) affected the response processes of the aid agencies. In addition, the findings of this study showed that the fuel crisis that happened in Nepal a few months after the earthquake reduced the efficiency of response processes by about 40%.

 

Broader Impacts

Knowledge-related: Our study contributed to advancing knowledge on infrastructure resilience through presentations at scholarly conferences (one presentation and one poster) and journal publications (one paper under review; two papers in preparation). It also contributed to enhancing education and the research infrastructure at the participating university through: (i) creation of a database of infrastructure damages and response processes; (ii) direct involvement of two graduate and one undergraduate students in research activities; and (iii) creation of resources (e.g., geo-tagged photo and infographic maps) to disseminate the finding to international aid agencies (e.g. USAID) and creation of case study materials for classroom teaching. 

Partnerships and Collaborations Related: The project helped strengthen institutional ties between the participating university and two research and academic institutions in Nepal, including the Kwopa Engineering College and Thribhuvan University. These collaborations included close interactions and participation of one faculty and five undergraduate students from Kwopa Engineering College in this project. In addition, this project strengthened interdisciplinary collaborations between the engineering and social science researchers in the team to advance the body of knowledge on infrastructure resilience.

Community Related: Our project allowed for transfer of lessons on infrastructure resilience in Nepal. Two presentations were made to academic and community audience in Bhaktapur to transfer the lessons learned from the preliminary results. Our project also made the community leaders and members of our selected Bhaktapur communities more aware of their infrastructure vulnerabilities and resilience enhancement needs. In addition, the findings provide important insights for international aid agencies involved in infrastructure development and recovery in developing countries.

Addendum # 1

Broader Theoretical Contributions: The study contributed to the theory of resilient infrastructure systems by studying the characteristics of infrastructure systems and infrastructure interdependencies in a developing county context and by offering novel methods of studying complex disaster response and recovery systems (Dynamic Network Analysis) and of measuring infrastructure recovery and resilience (peer-network framework). The results will be of interest to the broader scholarship on infrastructure management, disaster response, disaster recovery, disaster vulnerability and network analysis across a number of disciplines, including, but not limited to, civil engineering, public administration, geography, and urban planning.

Project Benefits to the U.S. Society: The findings of this study can help policy makers working for infrastructure agencies in the U.S. (e.g., Departments of Water Resources or Transportation at the state level) better understand infrastructure interdependencies and adopt strategies at different levels to develop resilient characteristics in infrastructure systems. Accordingly, the study can provide benefits for the broader public in the U.S. by helping enhance their safety and resilience in the face of disasters.
